properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected this evening. Cold westerly winds over the relatively warm waters of Georgian Bay have resulted in the development of lake effect flurries and snow squalls. Snow squalls are expected to weaken later this evening before tapering off to a few flurries overnight. Additional snowfall accumulations of 5 cm are possible in some areas by Tuesday morning. Additionally, strong westerly winds at times gusting to 60 km/h may result in areas of blowing snow resulting in poor visibilities especially along the Georgian Bay shoreline. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-07T16:08:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T00:09:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2635349713.2020

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this evening. Cold westerly winds over the relatively warm waters of Georgian Bay have resulted in the development of lake effect flurries and snow squalls. Additional snowfall accumulations of 2 to 5 cm are possible this evening. Snow squalls are expected to taper off to a few flurries later this evening. Additionally strong westerly winds at times gusting to 50 km/h may result in areas of blowing snow resulting in poor visibilities. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-07T14:11:17-00:00

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this evening. Cold westerly winds over the relatively warm waters of Georgian Bay and Lake Huron have resulted in the development of lake effect flurries and snow squalls. Motorists are advised that brief but intense snow squall bands and blowing snow could suddenly reduce visibilities this evening. Snow squalls are expected to taper off to a few flurries later this evening. Snowfall accumulations of near 5 cm with locally higher amounts will be possible in some areas by this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-07T14:12:32-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: More snow on Wednesday. Locations: Nova Scotia. Time span: Wednesday and persisting into Wednesday night. Remarks: A developing storm will give significant snowfall to the province on Wednesday. The snow will develop by dawn Wednesday over southwest Nova Scotia and spread across the province by noon. The snow will persist into the evening. While it is too soon to provide specific details on amounts, the potential exists for 15 to 30 cm of snow and strong winds giving reduced visibility in blowing snow. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-07T16:52:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T00:53:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2386463854.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific warm front will bring snow heavy at times to the central and north Okanagan tonight and Tuesday morning. Snow accumulations near 15 cm are expected with local amounts up to 20 cm possible near West Kelowna and Westbank. Snow will change to a few rain showers on Tuesday as warmer air moves into the region. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-07T16:00:16-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy on Wednesday. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h. Location: central and eastern Nova Scotia. Time span: Wednesday and persisting into Wednesday night. Remarks: A developing storm will give significant snowfall to the province on Wednesday. The snow will develop Wednesday morning and then begin to taper off in the evening over mainland Nova Scotia and overnight in Cape Breton. Current indications suggest total snowfall of 15 to 25 cm. Additionally, strong northerly winds will develop giving reduced visibility in blowing snow. Higher than normal water levels are expected at high tide Wednesday afternoon or evening along the Cape Breton coastline and the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T00:35:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T08:36:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3472327298.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm continues. A Pacific frontal system will transit across southern B.C. today bringing snow, heavy at times. Further snowfall amounts for today will be 10 to 15 cm. Snow is forecast to change to rain this afternoon for areas closer to the U.S. border as a milder southerly flow develops. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Heavy snowfall accumulation may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T03:56:44-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A Pacific weather system is expected to bring heavy snow to the Icefields Parkway, Highway 93, beginning late this afternoon. Snowfall totals are expected to be around 20 cm before the snow tapers off on Wednesday afternoon. Blowing snow in open areas is also expected to create snow drifts over the highway. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific frontal system will transit across southern B.C. today. Heavy snow will continue today and tonight giving 30 to 50 cm. Total accumulations near 70 cm is likely by Wednesday morning. Snow will ease Wednesday morning as the system exits the province. ### Rapidly accumulating snow and drifting snow will make travel very difficult. Poor weather conditions are likely to contribute to long-lasting transportation delays. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T04:00:26-00:00

Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A push of warm Pacific air aloft over colder air trapped at the surface will create favourable conditions for freezing rain. Heavy snowfall will transition to freezing rain this evening over the Similkameen region. The freezing rain may persist until early Tuesday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-07T16:04:39-00:00

Area: Similkameen

properties.Summary:

Snowfall warnings may need to be expanded towards the Saskatchewan border as the system develops. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of brief but intense snowfall are expected. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow. A band of intense snowfall extending from northwest of Sioux Lookout to south of Dryden is producing brief heavy snowfall and blowing snow. The band is moving southeast at 60 km/h. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: More snow and wind expected Wednesday night and Thursday. Possible total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm (5 to 10 cm Wednesday night, 5 to 10 cm Thursday) Possible wind gusts: Easterly 60 to 80 km/h (Wednesday evening), southwesterly 80 to 120 km/h (overnight Wednesday night), northwesterly 80 to 120 km/h (Thursday afternoon). Time span: Wednesday afternoon to Thursday evening. Remarks: A low pressure system will cross southeastern Newfoundland on Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Snow will begin along the south coast on Wednesday afternoon and spread elsewhere by evening. Precipitation will change over to rain or drizzle by Wednesday evening with some minor rainfall amounts possible. Precipitation will change back to snow again overnight Wednesday night before continuing into the day on Thursday. Any significant blowing snow will likely only occur Thursday afternoon after the snow redevelops and the temperatures fall below freezing. Conditions will improve in the south Thursday morning, but will linger in the east until Thursday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-08T00:33:35-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill temperatures near minus 40 degrees Celsius are expected overnight with slight warming during the daytime hours before cooling off again tomorrow night. Temperatures are not expected to warm significantly over the next week. The warning may need to be be expanded to areas to the south over the next couple of days. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T03:33:19-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Heavy snow will continue across the high elevation routes tonight. An additional 10 to 20 cm of snow will accumulate tonight. A stronger push of warm air tonight will create favourable conditions for freezing rain along sections of Highway 3 via Allison Pass and the Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt. The threat of freezing rain will end Tuesday morning as snow levels rise and the precipitation changes to rain. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-07T16:04:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T00:05:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0633877685.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values of -50 are being reported in Pond Inlet and Iqaluit. These wind chill values will moderate later this morning, but are likely to return to Pond Inlet Tuesday night. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T01:17:06-00:00

Area: Pond Inlet, Iqaluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected today. Lake effect snow squalls are expected to develop in a west flow off Lake Superior around midday today. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm will be possible along with significant reductions to visibility under the most intense bands. Snow squall activity will shift southward tonight as winds become northerly. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-08T00:39:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T08:40:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1843103553.2020
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. A Pacific warm front will bring snow heavy at times to the Shuswap region on Tuesday. Snow accumulations of 10 cm are expected near Sicamous and nearby communities. Snow will change to a few rain showers later on Tuesday as warmer air moves into the region. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-07T22:49:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-07T06:50:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3158085007.2020
Area: Shuswap
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm conditions likely Wednesday night and Thursday. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm (10 to 20 cm Wednesday night, 5 to 10 cm Thursday) Maximum wind gusts: Easterly 60 to 80 km/h (Wednesday night), north to northwesterly 80 to 120 km/h (Thursday). Time span: Wednesday afternoon to Thursday evening. Remarks: A low pressure system will cross southeastern Newfoundland on Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Snow will begin along the south coast on Wednesday afternoon and spread elsewhere by evening. Some areas in northeastern Newfoundland may see a brief change over to rain or drizzle overnight on Wednesday night before changing back to snow again on Thursday. Strong winds will combine with falling snow to reduce visibility in blowing snow, especially in the northeast on Thursday. Conditions will improve in the south and central by mid day on Thursday, but will continue in the west and northeast until Thursday evening. At this time, the Great Northern Peninsula may receive the least amount of snow, with potentially less snow than mentioned above. However, a shift in the track could bring those heavier amounts further north. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-08T00:32:28-00:00
